results.content: Manzoor has a good teaching style and covered the content well. I agree with the philosophy of jumping in an presenting some practical usage to provide real context, before doing any theory. Although there are many relevant libraries that could be delved into which are complimentary to WCF such as System.Threading, he covered WCF and the Web API very well.
results.content_html: Manzoor has a good teaching style and covered the content well. I agree with the philosophy of jumping in an presenting some practical usage to provide real context, before doing any theory. Although there are many relevant libraries that could be delved into which are complimentary to WCF such as System.Threading, he covered WCF and the Web API very well.

results.content:
Pro: Easy examples to understand and a nice gradual build up of the logic behind WCF.
Con: The poor pronunciation forces me to rewind more than necessary to try to grasp what you are actually saying. And the copy/pasting extends the length of the lectures if you want to follow the lecture by writing the code yourself.
results.content_html:
Pro: Easy examples to understand and a nice gradual build up of the logic behind WCF.
Con: The poor pronunciation forces me to rewind more than necessary to try to grasp what you are actually saying. And the copy/pasting extends the length of the lectures if you want to follow the lecture by writing the code yourself.

results.content: The instructor carefully explains each of the concepts and demonstrates them in code.  He does not assume anything; rather, he makes sure he has shown all the parts of each problem.  Also, he starts with basics and works his way up to more complex, which makes the more difficult parts easier to understand.

He does not assume anything; rather, he makes sure he has shown all the parts of each problem. Also, he starts with basics and works his way up to more complex, which makes the more difficult parts easier to understand.

results.content: This is a very good course especially if you have no experience in .NET. It does not assume an prior knowledge and builds your knowledge base with bare essentials. My only suggestion to improve on this course would be to beef up a bit on the WebAPI front with common examples of REST based API which don't follow the basic conventional approach.
results.content_html: This is a very good course especially if you have no experience in .NET. It does not assume an prior knowledge and builds your knowledge base with bare essentials. My only suggestion to improve on this course would be to beef up a bit on the WebAPI front with common examples of REST based API which don't follow the basic conventional approach.

results.content: The EndPoint seems a bit quick and sketchy. Hopefully it will be explained in later lessons. Some of the lessons where sketchy in parts. You need to have a deep understanding of some of the C# commands and principals before taking this course to fully appreciate it.
results.content_html: The EndPoint seems a bit quick and sketchy. Hopefully it will be explained in later lessons. Some of the lessons where sketchy in parts. You need to have a deep understanding of some of the C# commands and principals before taking this course to fully appreciate it.

results.content:
The pre-requisites were not clear. The lectures seem to start abruptly without any proper introduction.

The videos seem to be lifted from a YouTube channel and lack professionalism with a strange introduction sequence (you feel you are underwater).
Most of the time, zoom-out and zoom-in are inappropriate. The explanation and activity happen out of screen. This is tiring. It takes a while (almost 25% of the course) to get adjusted to the pace and delivery of the content.

Later during the course, there is a sudden shift from WCF to Web API. Probably that should've been a different course. Some of the videos in this section are split into two parts abruptly. An introduction to MVC would've been appropriate.
results.content_html:
The pre-requisites were not clear. The lectures seem to start abruptly without any proper introduction.

The videos seem to be lifted from a YouTube channel and lack professionalism with a strange introduction sequence (you feel you are underwater).
Most of the time, zoom-out and zoom-in are inappropriate. The explanation and activity happen out of screen. This is tiring. It takes a while (almost 25% of the course) to get adjusted to the pace and delivery of the content.

Later during the course, there is a sudden shift from WCF to Web API. Probably that should've been a different course. Some of the videos in this section are split into two parts abruptly. An introduction to MVC would've been appropriate.

results.content: This is definitely a brilliant introduction to WCF and Web API. Having almost completed the course, i can say I have learnt a lot and now feeling confident in WCF and Web API which in the past i wasn't that confident in. I would have liked to see the instructor build a real application using Web API. That would have made me give a 5 star. Other than that i recommend this course to anyone trying to get their feet wet in WCF and Web API.
results.content_html: This is definitely a brilliant introduction to WCF and Web API. Having almost completed the course, i can say I have learnt a lot and now feeling confident in WCF and Web API which in the past i wasn't that confident in. I would have liked to see the instructor build a real application using Web API. That would have made me give a 5 star. Other than that i recommend this course to anyone trying to get their feet wet in WCF and Web API.

results.content:
Very good course about WCF and Web APi's. 
Suggestion: Please add one more section to differentiate them. Are they both similar? Their both motive is same? Implementation is same.
results.content_html:
Very good course about WCF and Web APi's.

results.content:
Missing code for the ASP application....

Missing parts:
- Description/analysis of the different concurrency models (Single, Reentrant, Multiple) missing.
- Basic description/analysis of streaming missing.
- Description/analysis of message based streaming (Header, Body, MessageContract, MessageHeader, MessageBodyMember) missing.
- No exercises

Otherwise interesting and with surgical examples.
results.content_html:
Missing code for the ASP application....

Missing parts:
- Description/analysis of the different concurrency models (Single, Reentrant, Multiple) missing.
- Basic description/analysis of streaming missing.
- Description/analysis of message based streaming (Header, Body, MessageContract, MessageHeader, MessageBodyMember) missing.
- No exercises

Otherwise interesting and with surgical examples.

results.content: Would have been great if you could explain why we are doing each step more conceptually and what occurs in the background,instead of just explaining the steps to do.
results.content_html: Would have been great if you could explain why we are doing each step more conceptually and what occurs in the background,instead of just explaining the steps to do.

results.content: Great content in breadth and depth. The examples given made sense and were easy to follow. The only thing that would enhance the course would be to have exercises for the students to go through and walk-through of the solution afterwards.

results.content:
At the end of the Endpoints Implementation II, he should have provided a list a of the various steps he had to go through to get a working application.  That would have been helpful for people when they come to develop a web service.

In the two previous lectures, he was a little redundant, repeating the same information twice.   His diagrams with cartoon characters were just plain goofy, and misleading because he used the same two characters for both the client and service.  And the sequences with real people  expressing confusion or disgust, or comprehension and contentment are absurd - an insult to one's intelligence.  We are not little kids here!

If not for these defects, I would have given 5 stars.
results.content_html:
At the end of the Endpoints Implementation II, he should have provided a list a of the various steps he had to go through to get a working application. That would have been helpful for people when they come to develop a web service.

In the two previous lectures, he was a little redundant, repeating the same information twice. His diagrams with cartoon characters were just plain goofy, and misleading because he used the same two characters for both the client and service. And the sequences with real people expressing confusion or disgust, or comprehension and contentment are absurd - an insult to one's intelligence. We are not little kids here!

If not for these defects, I would have given 5 stars.
